facts.text: Appeal filed in Supreme Court as Civil Appeal No. XII of 1950 from High Court of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: APPEAL from the High Court of Judicature at Bombay Civil Appeal No. XII of 1950. This was an appeal from a judgment

facts.text: High Court of Bombay delivered judgment and order dated 2nd September 1947 by Chagla Acting C.J. and Bhagwati J. in Appeal No. 60 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: This was an appeal from a judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay  Chagla, Acting C.J. and Bhagwati J.  dated 2nd September, 1947, in Appeal No. 60 of 1946. The facts are fully set out in the judgment.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on 27 May 1950 by Kania C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. May 27. The judgment of the Court was delivered by KANIA C.J.--This is an appeal from a judgment of the High Court at Bombay and it relates to the jurisdiction of the

facts.text: Respondent company borrowed money from Central Bank of India Ltd. at Bombay for its business.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companypany, for its business, borrowed money from the Central Bank of India Ltd. at Bombay. In order to secure the loan a document was executed on the 22nd

facts.text: Document executed on 22nd March 1945 to secure the loan, stamped with Rs. 16-8-0 as deed of hypothecation without possession.

anchor.surface_text: In order to secure the loan a document was executed on the 22nd of March, 1945, with a stamp of Rs. 16-8-0, on the footing that it was a, deed of hypothecation without possession of the goods.

facts.text: Sub-Registrar impounded the document and sent it to the Stamp Office for registration.

anchor.surface_text: When the deed was sent to the Sub-Registrar for registration he impounded the same and sent it to the Stamp Office. The Assistant Superintendent of Stamps wrote to the respondent

facts.text: Assistant Superintendent of Stamps determined document was mortgage with possession, chargeable under article 40(a) of Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Superintendent of Stamps wrote to the respondent that the document was a mortgage with possession, chargeable with duty under article 40  a  of the Schedule and inquired

facts.text: Respondent's solicitors contended document was not mortgage with possession, no possession given or intended except contingencies, properly stamped.

anchor.surface_text: that the document was number, and was never intended by the parties to be, a mortgage with possession. They pointed out that numberpossession of the property had been given or was intended to be given,

facts.text: Assistant Superintendent imposed duty of Rs. 56,250 and penalty of Rs. 5,000.

anchor.surface_text: In reply the Assistant Superintendent intimated that the docu- ment was chargeable with duty of Rs. 56,250 and a penalty of Rs. 5,000 had been imposed. The respondents were asked to pay

facts.text: Respondent filed suit on 27th July 1945 against Central Bank contending document not mortgage with possession, seeking court direction and possible rectification.

anchor.surface_text: On the 27th July, 1945, the respondent filed a suit against the Central Bank companytending that the document was number a mortgage with possession. It was alleged that since a doubt had arisen

facts.text: On 9th August 1945, respondent's solicitors informed Assistant Superintendent of suit and requested not to press demand.

anchor.surface_text: On 9th August, 1945, the respondents solicitors informed the Assistant Superintendent that such a suit had been filed and requested that the demand for payment of stamp duty and penalty

facts.text: Collector sent demand letter on 17th January 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector thereafter sent a letter to the respondents on the 17th January, 1946, demanding payment. On the 25th of January, 1946, the suit filed by the respond- ent was disposed

facts.text: Suit disposed on 25th January 1946, rectification as prayed ordered by court.

anchor.surface_text: On the 25th of January, 1946, the suit filed by the respond- ent was disposed of by the Court and the rectification as prayed was ordered.

facts.text: Respondent's solicitors intimated suit result and sent copy of rectified deed to Assistant Superintendent and Collector.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents solicitors immediately intimated the result of the suit to the Assistant Superin- tendent and sent a companyy of the deed showing the rectifica- tions made in the original document.

facts.text: On 1st February 1946, respondent's solicitors enquired if Assistant Superintendent agreeable to reference under section 56(2).

anchor.surface_text: On the 1st February, 1946, the respondents solictors enquired of the Assistant Superintendent of Stamps whether he was agree- able to make a reference under section 56  2  to the appel- lant,

facts.text: Petition filed to appellant on 5th February 1946 to rescind order or refer case under section 57.

anchor.surface_text: as the question of liability to pay the stamp duty and. penalty involved important questions of law. A petition on behalf of the respondent to the appellant was also filed on the 5th

facts.text: Petition rejected by appellant on 4th July 1946.

anchor.surface_text: of February in which it was prayed that either the order of the Assistant Superintendent of Stamps be rescinded or in the alternative a case may be referred under section 57 of the Stamp Act. This petition was rejected on the 4th July, 1946.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition in High Court on 19th July 1946 for writ of certiorari or order under s.45 Specific Relief Act or direction under s.57.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent there- upon filed a petition in the High Court on the 19th of July, 1946, praying that a writ of certiorari may be issued against the appellant, or an order may be made against him under section 45 of the Specific Relief Act,

facts.text: Mr. Justice Blagden denied certiorari but directed appellant to state case under s.57.

anchor.surface_text: The matter came for hearing before Mr. Justice Blagden who did number grant the first relief but directed the appellant to state a case under section 57 of the Stamp Act to the Court for its opinion.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeal in High Court against Blagden J's order but failed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an appeal but failed. He has number companye in appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Appellant appeals to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an appeal but failed. He has number companye in appeal to this Court. Two points have been urged on behalf of the appelant.

facts.text: High Court directed appellant to state case under s.57 despite s.226(1) Government of India Act 1935 argument.

anchor.surface_text: The second point is whether having regard to the terms of section 226  1 of the Government of India Act, 1935, the High Court had jurisdiction to order the appellant to state the case,

facts.text: Suit court ordered rectification of instrument indicating common intention not mortgage with possession.

issues.text: whether under section 57 of the Stamp Act there is an obligation on the appellant to state a case, and if not whether the High Court had jurisdiction to give a direction to that effect

anchor.surface_text: The first is whether under section 57 of the Stamp Act there is an obligation on the appellant to state a case, and if not whether the High Court had jurisdiction to give a direction to that effect.

issues.text: whether having regard to the terms of section 226(1) of the Government of India Act, 1935, the High Court had jurisdiction to order the appellant to state the case, it being a matter relating to the revenue. Under this head it is also argued that the matter had proceeded beyond the stage of assessment and had reached the stage of recovery

anchor.surface_text: The second point is whether having regard to the terms of section 226 1 of the Government of India Act, 1935, the High Court had jurisdiction to order the appellant to state the case, it being a matter relating to the revenue. Under this head it is also argued that the matter had proceeded beyond the stage of assessment and,had reached the stage of recovery.

arguments.claim: Section 57 of the Stamp Act gives only a discretionary power to the Chief Controlling Revenue-authority to state a case, not an obligation

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it is contended that the very words of section 57 of the Stamp Act show that it is a power given to the appellant to state a case and it is not an obligation. The section is framed and worded only to give the benefit thereof to the appellant and it is not for the benefit of any other party.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Court to send a statement of case to the appellant and the High Court respectively, in our opinion, instead of helping the appellant, go against his c

arguments.court_reasoning: Overlooks that reference benefits party affected; power coupled with obligation when important question of law arises; supported by precedent

arguments.claim: The word 'may' in section 57 was deliberately used to confer a power only for the benefit of the authority, not other parties

anchor.surface_text: The word may used in the section was deliberately used for that purpose. It was pointed out that under section 56 2 of the Stamp Act if the Collector felt doubt as to the amount of duty with which the instrument was chargeable he may draw up a statement of the case

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Court to send a statement of case to the appellant and the High Court respectively, in our opinion, instead of helping the appellant, go against his c

arguments.court_reasoning: Absence of 'feels doubt' in s57 indicates broader purpose benefiting affected party

arguments.claim: Sections 56(2) and 60 use 'may' similarly, giving power only to referring authority for its own benefit, no right for other parties to insist

anchor.surface_text: Similarly under section 60 if any Court felt doubt as to the amount of duty to be paid it was given power to draw up a statement of case for the opinion of the High Court. It was argued that both these sections gave only power to the Collector and the Court to make a reference for their own benefit.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f this Act or of any rule thereunder, the Chief Revenue Authority may, either on its own motion or on reference from any Revenue officer subordinate t

arguments.court_reasoning: These sections apply when referring authority in doubt; s57 broader, for benefit of affected party

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, it was contended that the scheme of the Stamp Act was materially different from the scheme of the Income Tax Act. In our opinion the appellants contentions are unsound.

arguments.claim: Power in s57 is coupled with duty when important question of law arises; High Court can direct performance

anchor.surface_text: But when a capacity or power is given to a public authority there may be circumstances which couple with the power a duty to exercise it. ... In our opinion, the power contained in section 57 is in the nature of an obligation or is coupled with an obligation

arguments.claim: S57 reference enures to benefit of affected party, unlike assumption it's only for authority

anchor.surface_text: The absence of the words feels doubt as to the amount of duty to be paid in respect of an instrument in section 57 supports the view that the reference contemplated under that section is not for the benefit of the appellant only but enures also for the benefit of the party affected by the assessment.

arguments.claim: Alcock case applies; principles from Julius v Bishop of Oxford: power coupled with duty in nature of thing

anchor.surface_text: To use the language of Lord Cairns in the case of Julius v. Bishop of Oxford There may be something in the nature of the thing empowered to be done, something in the object for which it is to be done, something in the conditions under which it is to be done,

arguments.claim: Scheme of Stamp Act: s57 resolves conflicts between officer and party; not finality for authority

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the Stamp Act may be briefly noticed. Chapter II contains provisions about the liability of instruments to duty ... Section 57 1 falls under this heading.

arguments.claim: Ordering revenue officer to perform statutory duty not original jurisdiction concerning revenue under s226(1)

anchor.surface_text: In their Lordships view the order of a High Court to a revenue officer to do his statutory duty would not be the exercise of original jurisdiction in any matter concerning the revenue.

arguments.claim: Assistant Superintendent correctly determined document as mortgage with possession under art 40(a)

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Superintendent of Stamps wrote to the respondent that the document was a mortgage with possession, chargeable with duty under article 40 a of the Schedule and inquired why it was not duly stamped before execution.

holdings.text: The power contained in section 57 of the Stamp Act is in the nature of an obligation or is coupled with an obligation and under the circumstances can be demanded to be used also by the parties affected by the assessment of the stamp duty; it is coupled with a duty cast on the Chief Controlling Revenue-authority, as a public officer, to make a reference when an important and intricate question of law arises, and the Court has power to direct him to do so if he omits.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the power contained in section 57 is in the nature of an obligation or is coupled with an obliga- tion and under the circumstances can be demanded to be used also by the parties affected by the assessment of the stamp duty. Our attention has been drawn in this connection to the decision

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects pure discretion argument via textual analysis (absence of 'doubt' unlike s56/60), purposive interpretation benefiting affected party, scheme of Act resolving officer-party conflicts, precedent from Alcock (analogous Income Tax s51) and Julius v Bishop (power coupled with duty based on nature/object).

holdings.text: The High Court has jurisdiction to order the Chief Controlling Revenue-authority to state a case under section 57 notwithstanding section 226(1) of the Government of India Act, 1935, as such an order is not the exercise of original jurisdiction in any matter concerning the revenue but compelling performance of statutory duty; the stage of recovery is irrelevant as the relief does not obstruct revenue duties.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the present case also, the respondent seeks the Courts intervention to make the appellant perform his statutory duty to state a case. That is not exercising the original jurisdiction of the Court in any matter concerning the revenue. It is only asking the appellant to perform his statutory duty. The further argu- ment that the proceedings in this case had passed beyond

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Alcock precedent rejecting similar jurisdictional bar under GOI Act 1915 s106(2); distinguishes as not original revenue jurisdiction but mandamus-like compulsion of public duty; recovery stage does not alter as no obstruction to collection.

precedents.citation: Alcock, Ashdown Co. Ltd. v. Chief Revenue Authority, Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Alcock, Ashdown Co. Ltd. v. Chief Revenue Authority, Bombay 1 . In that case a question arose about an asses- sees right to ask the Commissioner of Income Tax to state a case for the opinion of the Court under section 51 of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1918.

precedents.case_name: Alcock Ashdown & Co Ltd v Chief Revenue Authority Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Chief Revenue Authority has duty to state case to High Court on serious question of law interpretation, and court can direct if refused; power coupled with duty
precedents.cited_holding: If the assessee applies for a case the Authority must state it unless frivolous or unnecessary... there does lie a duty upon the Chief Revenue Authority to state a case... it is in the power of the Court to control him and to order him to state a case.

anchor.surface_text: the principle being exemplified in the case of Spooner v. Juddow 1   and upon section 106 2 of the Government of India Act, 1915.

precedents.cited_proposition: exemplifies exclusion of revenue matters from consideration of ordinary civil courts

anchor.surface_text: To use the language of Lord Cairns in the case of Julius v. Bishop of Oxford 1  There may be something in the nature of the thing empowered to be done, something in the object for which it is to be done, something in the conditions under which it is to be done, something in the title of the person or persons for whose benefit the power is to be exercised, which may couple the power with a duty

precedents.cited_proposition: a capacity or power given to a public authority may be coupled with a duty to exercise it under certain circumstances
precedents.cited_holding: There may be something in the nature of the thing empowered to be done... which may couple the power with a duty, and make it the duty of the person in whom the power is reposed to exercise that power when called upon to do so.

anchor.surface_text: the present case was sought to be distinguished from Alcocks case 1 . In our opinion this argument of the appellant must also fail. A similar argument based on the wording of the corresponding section 106 2 of the Government of India Act, 1915, as mentioned above, was urged in Alcocks case 1 .

precedents.case_name: Alcock Ashdown & Co Ltd v Chief Revenue Authority Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: argument based on exclusion of revenue jurisdiction rejected; court can compel revenue officer to perform statutory duty
precedents.cited_holding: the order of a High Court to a revenue officer to do his statutory duty would not be the exercise of original jurisdiction in any matter concerning the revenue
